text: Mutual information is good, but it doesn't handle second order information. IE: if two features need special preprocessing to become valuable it can't say anything about it. A good example might be something cyclic that can be flattened? maybe

elements.text: Mutual information is good, but it doesn't handle second order information. IE: if two features need special preprocessing to become valuable it can't say anything about it. A good example might be something cyclic that can be flattened? maybe

text: But yea here's the fun part about the question you've asked. If you could generically determine if a dataset could be used/manipulated to regress/classify/whatever another property. You may end up solving the artificial intelligence problem hehehe. I tried once, and ended up making some weird unsupervised decision tree. Got a paper out of it, but thats it lol

text:
I have a few questions. I'm thinking that its context dependent for the problem and model.

1) Is the data "supervised/labeled" in the sense that your "output variables" (if any?) are already in the dataset and you just want to find some relationship between input variables and output variables? And then use that relationship to solve your problem.

 Perhaps your data is not labeled, and you're trying to achieve something else.

2) And do you mean before making a model? i.e. someone hands you data and you want to be able to convince them and say "this is insufficient" before spending a lot of time of trying to make a model/analysis of sorts

text:
In anycase, I would say domain expertise and knowledge of the "system" would help. Though haha thats a vague answer and not very helpful.

Because on one hand your domain knowledge might give you intuition/gut-feeling that what you are trying to do is possible.

On a deeper level. It also depends on your satisfication level to the answer at hand. For example, take an image of a face. Discard 80% of the pixels randomly all over the image. This reduced set of pixels is the data that you give to someone. You tell them want them to reconstruct the face.

• One perspective is that its impossible. Any guess you have it just "making data" up.
• On another hand you get actually get a really good answer because there's an inherent structure in how natural images look like. Using techniques from Compressed Sensing you can actually make a really really good guess of the face. (I can't find an example right now unfortunately. But I remember there was a website that showed a face of US President Obama or something deleted a lot of pixels, then used L1/sparsity techniques to reconstruct the entire face)

text: Hey <@U0138UTB7A4> and <@UPUBAM63X> - Kim, the second point you raised nails it right on the head. Didn't know how to phrase it exactly. Thus my vague wording. Could you elaborate more on the notion of domain expertise and knowledge? Also, Casey, does that help clarify what I was looking for a bit more? Also, I think the question boils down to representation in somewhat the same vein as you mentioned. I am just wondering if there are rule-of-thumb screening heuristics/mental models one could use to quickly determine if a dataset is well equipped to answer the questions you are trying to answer with it.

elements.text: Hey
and

- Kim, the second point you raised nails it right on the head. Didn't know how to phrase it exactly. Thus my vague wording. Could you elaborate more on the notion of domain expertise and knowledge? Also, Casey, does that help clarify what I was looking for a bit more? Also, I think the question boils down to representation in somewhat the same vein as you mentioned. I am just wondering if there are rule-of-thumb screening heuristics/mental models one could use to quickly determine if a dataset is well equipped to answer the questions you are trying to answer with it.

text:
So basically it depends on the question you are asking. Based on the question you are asking there are statistical assumptions being made, so you have to check those first. Then you can do an empirical test of asking the question :stuck_out_tongue:. Data science is best practiced as a science. Formulate a hypothesis -> etc.

That said, domain knowledge can help you weed out certain things. Like would flight records from 1920-1940 help us answer questions about 2020 airline tickets? Probably not!

elements.text: So basically it depends on the question you are asking. Based on the question you are asking there are statistical assumptions being made, so you have to check those first. Then you can do an empirical test of asking the question

. Data science is best practiced as a science. Formulate a hypothesis -> etc.

That said, domain knowledge can help you weed out certain things. Like would flight records from 1920-1940 help us answer questions about 2020 airline tickets? Probably not!

text: but even if you have domain knowledge, it's best not to get expertise bias. Analytical and statistical minds think in likelihoods not in absolutes. So saying outright "there's nothing in the 1920's data! don't even open it" aren't doing it right... Would you put it at top priority though? nope.

text: I've been wondering this same question.  I've set aside next Wednesday to really try to grok Andrew Gelman's "Bayesian workflow" in case it has the answers: <https://arxiv.org/abs/2011.01808>  but I don't think there are any guarantees, not really.

attachments.title: Bayesian Workflow
attachments.text: The Bayesian approach to data analysis provides a powerful way to handle uncertainty in all observations, model parameters, and model structure using probability theory. Probabilistic programming...

elements.text: I've been wondering this same question.  I've set aside next Wednesday to really try to grok Andrew Gelman's "Bayesian workflow" in case it has the answers:

text: I would definitely be interested in hearing how others use domain knowledge to determine if a data set is adequate to address a problem you want to solve.

root.text: Hey, how do you all quickly determine when a dataset you are working with does not have the data you need to address a problem you want to solve?

elements.text: Hey, how do you all quickly determine when a dataset you are working with does not have the data you need to address a problem you want to solve?
I would definitely be interested in hearing how others use domain knowledge to determine if a data set is adequate to address a problem you want to solve.

text:
But I guess for myself, I imagine that what I meant by domain knowledge / expertise is to know at least there might be a plausible chain/network of cause-effect relationships that might "propagate information" between the information of interest thats helpful to solving your (data science) problem and the pieces of information that you might already have.

For example in PDE inverse problems like lets say microwave imaging, you at least know that the microwaves are at least modified/disrupted by the thing inside the chamber that you are measuring from. So that you know that maybe it'll give you insight on how to image the thing inside based on how the waves are scattered/reflected.

Or for predicting mosquito populations you might know from biology that standing water is important to their reproductive cycle so you might say that using weather data is key to that and part of the "system"/(differential equations?).

I think this whole thing is a spectrum from obvious connections in possible causality/information gleening, to very unclear causes-effects.

These are very loose vague terms because I'm not sure how to quantify these perspectives/gut feelings I have on domain expertise.

I'd love to hear your thoughts on this! Its a pretty interesting topic. I would love to get better tips on how to navigate this / finetune my own perspective.

And I think <@UPUBAM63X> is right about prioritization and bias and how its best to not to get too confident about knowing the system, you might get surprised on what relationships there might be.
